title: How many confirmed cases of COVID-19 in the US will be reported for the week ending 1 May 2021?
preds: The downward trend is unmistakable, the only question is whether that momentum will take the count below 350. So far, 5 days ~ 250K- which hardly helps in separating these two intervals. I am going to give < 350 an edge so it will be 60:40.

Between today and tomorrow, will there be another 104,074 COVID cases in the U.S.?  It is going to be close.  Hopefully, we can get today's numbers before the question closes tonight.  For now, I am maintaining my forecast.

If the last two days of this week (April 30 and May 1) will be less than 92% of last week's numbers, it will remain <350k.
Getting more cautious here, as April 28 (88% of last week's Wednesday), and April 29 (86% of 7 days earlier) came close to 92%.
Changing 90% for <350k to 83% (5 in 6 chance).

From April 25th to 28th there have been around 180,000 confirmed cases of covid in the US. With a daily average varying from 40 to 60 thousands new cases every day and two days left in the week, it can be assumed that there would be around 260 to 300 thousand new cases of covid in total during the week ending May 1st 2020.
5 day count ~ 241K, so it seems like a toss-up between 250-350 & 350-450. Slightly nervous for differing significantly from the consensus.
Another one that is going to be close, but the new case rate seems to be declining pretty fast this week.  Going to flip my forecast.

Just scanning through the state charts, most states look like they're on a downward trend, particularly those that are more populous or have higher cases, so I would guess the ~9k daily drop in weekly confirmed cases continues, putting it somewhere around 340 to 345.

184214 cases this week (Sunday to Wednesday), 79% of the same 4 days last week.
Only if the last remaining three days will be >= 91% of Thursday to Saturday last week, the number for the entire week will be >350k.
As Wednesday was 85% of last week, I wouldn’t rule out > 350k, but see it as *almost* settled for < 350k.
Cases continue to drop... ~130K for 3 days, so 250-350 looking more likely. However need to be mindful of a midweek pick-up, hence being a bit conservative.

New cases of COVID in the U.S. is dropping pretty clearly this week and looks to be close plus or minus around 350,000.  I am adjusting my forecast by zeroing out "More than 450,000 but fewer than 550,000" and reallocate to "More than 250,000 but fewer than 350,000".  Still accounting for a slight surge or updated reporting that results in number going over 350,000.

129936 cases total in 3 days until yesterday (April 25-27), 
4 days left (April 28 - May 1).
350000-129936 = 220064 cases to reach 350k
A week ago (April 21-April 24), there were 245876 cases in the last 4 days of the week.
220064 would be 90% of 245876.
So far, in this week (April 25-27) there were 76% of cases compared to the week before (April 18-20).
If for rest of the week it will also be 76% of the previous week, it is going to be 316523.

25th and 26th total about 80k.  This means need 74k per day over next 5 days and the trend is downward and there hasn’t been this level for a while.  So I think it will now be difficult to get past 350k.

33.7k cases 2 days ago, 19% below the weekly low on the same day 1 week ago. 47.4k cases yesterday, significantly lower than 1 week ago. Update 4/28: it's a tight forecast, but it's solid. 7 day moving averages for the past few days:
4/23: 59.9k
4/24: 59.5k
4/25: 58.4k
4/26: 55.1k
4/27: 53.8k
Falling by an average of 1.5k/day over this period. We just have to get to <50k/day. We will be there within 4 days.
Total for April 25 to 27: 33,662 + 47,430 + 51,938 = 133,030. (By this time last week, we saw 172.8k cases.) 216,969 cases remaining to stay under 350k. Need to stay under 216969/4 = 54.2k cases/day average for the rest of the week. Update 4/29: 54,520 cases 4/28. Total for April 25‐28 now 133,030 + 54,520 = 187,550. 349,999 ‐ 187,550 = 162,449 cases remaining for the next 3 days to stay under 350k. Must stay under average of 162,449/3 cases/day = ~54,150 cases/day for the rest of the week. April 25 was the lowest reporting day of the week. May 1 will be the 2nd lowest and will likely be in the 40k's. I can't see 4/29 and 4/30 being much higher than 54k/day, and there's a little room for those days to be higher because 5/1 will be lower. Also, the 7‐day moving average has already moved from 59.5k/day for 4/24 to 52.6k/day for 4/28, and there are 3 more days to go. The forecast still holds. Update 4/30: current total at 246,078. 58.5k reported today. 103921 to go to stay under 350k. Anticipate May 1 in low 40k's. Forecast holds even if 4/30 comes in close to 60k. Update 5/1: 58,338 cases today. 304416 total. 45,583 to go. I'm certain May 1 will be under that.

I have to accept I misjudged this, believing that influencing factors would almost cancel out to result in a gradual increase rather than a decline in numbers over the last two weeks. Now forecasting 345-370K but hedging against earlier forecasts.

April 25 + 26: 79272 cases = 72% of April 18 + 19.
If the entire week is 72 % of week earlier: 300719 cases.
Going 100% for 250k-350k. 
(@belikewater knew it all along)

2 days clocking at roughly 40K/day means next 5 days need roughly 75K/day to breach 450K. US had 75K + cases/day nearly two weeks ago + vaccination pace is brisk. Hence downgrading 450-550 to 10%. Equally, it's possible that US has only ~ 55K/day  for the next 5 days and we could end up below 350K. These two scenarios seem equiprobable- hence updating it to 10%.

A new weekly low was reached with yesterday's cases: 33.7k, down 7.9k (19.0%) from 4/18.
4/18: 41.6k, down 6.4k (13.3%) from 4/11.
4/11: 48.0k
The trend increasingly looks like it's headed lower for the week.

Maintaining my forecast for now, but the 350,000 to 450,000 range would appear to be the most likely.  Number of cases are declining, so can not rule out 250,000 to 350,000.  Still need to account for an unforeseen surge or reporting correction upward this week.

Yesterday (25.4.) only 31962 new cases  - although number is not final, this is a siginificant drop (-24%) to 7 days before.
We need only a 12% drop to fall under 350k.

Week's total 10/04/21 - 17/04/21: 430,000 cases
Week's total 17/04/21 - 24/04/21: 420,000 cases General trend appears to be on a slow downward decline.  No obvious Black Swans in the next week that appear likely to fundamentally alter this trend line outside the "350,000 - 450,000" bucket (with projected total between 410,000 and 420,000).  Whilst this is a fragile forecast (it wouldn't take much to bunt next week's total into the next door bucket) there is also the general trend line of the last two months to take some confidence in. https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&pickerSort=desc&pickerMetric=total_cases&Metric=Confirmed+cases&Interval=Cumulative&Relative+to+Population=false&Align+outbreaks=false&country=~USA
Compensating for earlier forecasts having weighting towards 470k -  now expecting reduction towards 430k based on recent data
The downward trend is much stronger ~ almost no chance of 550K plus << 1%. About a third chance of ending up in 450-550. About 2/3 chance of coming in 350-450.
Betting on current trends accelerating slightly.

April 16: 70.1k cases/day, 7 day average.
April 23: 60.0k cases/day, 7 day average.
Losing 10.0k cases/day/week. Extrapolating linearly: 
April 30: 50.0k cases/day, 7 day average.
50.0k * 7 = 350.0k
Will this linear trend continue? I don't know. Weather and vaccination are working in favor of declining cases/day. If it accelerates, we'll be in bin 3!

Entering data from https://covidactnow.org/ into a spreadsheet I calculated the correlation between the percent vaccinated (1+ Dose) and the infection rate.  Over the past few days the correlation has increased significantly, reaching -0.41 today.  States with higher vaccination rates are beginning to show a tendency to have lower reinfection rates, Rt.  This is to be expected, but until recently there hasn't been much correlation. New Hampshire has by far the highest vaccination rate, at 59%; Mississippi has the lowest at 30.2%.  Such a large difference, nearly two to one, may indicate that vaccine hesitancy is having an increasing effect on the statistics.  Going forward I expect this to develop into "a thing," i.e., there will be news stories about towns, counties, and states that are lagging in vaccination numbers, and leading in new infections.  IMHO, one month from now the difference between the best and the worst states & counties will be headline news. Only one week remains before this question closes.  If the present rate of decrease continues then new infections for the week ending May 1 will be 334k, with an estimated error band of +/-20k.
The downward trend is stronger, which  makes the bucket B5- highly unlikely and makes B3 (350-450) more likely. Next couple of days should tell us more!

Rationale is to look at the current 7-day moving average trend on the Main John Hopkins website and the overall trend, taking into account state by state patterns, the state of the vaccination roll out, announcements on further roll out and the likelihood of any changes to issues like borders and potential super spreader events like major holidays or sporting events. Finally need to consider any patterns in variants around the world.  Also I should do better as I am forecasting close to the time.

The spike in the new COVID case appears to be subsiding, suggesting that case counts will begin to decline over the next week to around 50,000 new cases per day.  It is possible that with the rising vaccination rate we a beginning to see the final decline.

The average Rt for the 50 states + DC has fallen below 1.00 for the first time in nearly a month -- to 0.995.  See https://covidactnow.org/?s=1769690.  It reached a peak of 1.05 on April 4.  There is a weekly cycle in the numbers, with a peak every weekend and a valley mid-week.  But the overall trend appears to have broken to the downside.  I believe vaccinations are beginning to have an effect (finally). More than once I have forecasted the start of a decline in new infections, and ended up on the wrong side of the bet.  But even a stopped clock is right twice a day.  Once again I will bet that new infections will continue to decline until May 1, with a mid-point forecast of 357k/week.  This is a short-term question, so we'll know the result soon.
The confirmed cases aren´t going down since more than a month, so it´s likely that it would be in the week ending 1st may like today.

Week ending Apr 17 numbers ~ 480K. This suggest that 350-450K bucket should become a bit more likely. The number of tests per positive case continues to fall (which indicated the numbers may be understated and will correct), but the number of tests is also decreasing. A likely explanation is the Spring break and the daily count in the next few days should indicate the broad trend.

67.5k per day at the moment = 472.5k for a week
Threshold for 450k = 64.3k per day
Threshold for 550k = 78.5k per day Current rate 68k per day. Rates in New York seem to be dropping fast and some of the other larger states have plateaued.  A drop in a couple of the big states could have a large impact on the outcome of this question.
Update. Average cases/day grew ~8% in the past 2 weeks. Currently at ~70k/day. Project ~70k/day * 1.08 = ~75.6k/day 7 day moving average for the end of the month; 75.6 * 7 = ~530k cases.

Si vemos el aumento de casos por dia en estados unidos durante las ultimas semanas, podemos notar que estos fluctuan entre los 60000 y 80000. Además, según el new york times, el promedio de casos diarios a nivel nacional es de 70000.
Con la informacion anterior, podemos deducir que es muy probable que este promedio se mantenga, ya que esta ha sido la tendencia durante las ultimas semas, por lo que con setenta mil casos diarios por una semana, eso da un total de 490 mil casos. 
Por otro lado siempre existe la probabilidad de que algo ocurra que distorcione un poco la curva, ya sea medidas dictadas por las autoridades, efectos de la vacunacion, etc. Por esto decidí asignar un minimo porcentaje a los rangos [350,450] y [550,650].

Elegí pronosticar la cantidad de nuevos casos de COVID confirmados para la última semana de abril en Estados Unidos. Según New York Times para el 14 de abril, el promedio de casos nuevos por día para el mes de abril es de 71.000. Es decir, si mantenemos este promedio "intacto" obtendríamos un total de 71.000*7 = 497.000 casos para la última semana de abril. Sin embargo, según la misma revista, este promedio habría aumentado en 16.000 con respecto al mes de marzo, un aumento del 30%. Por lo tanto, teniendo en cuenta esta tendencia y asumiendo linealidad en el aumento del promedio, podríamos asumir que, para esta última semana de abril, este promedio habrá aumentado entre un (30*3/4)%  con respecto al valor 71.000. Por lo que se tendrían alrededor de 86.975 nuevos casos en promedio por día, siendo un total de 608.825 en total para la semana, aproximadamente. Tomando en cuenta el escenario chileno, en el que, a mayor cantidad de inoculados, mayor fueron los casos confirmados, creo que lo más prudente es pronosticar hacia valores mayores de 608.000. También coloqué un posible escenario en el que, contra todo pronóstico, los casos se verían disminuidos. No obstante, esto podría ocurrir solo si medidas de mayor calado fuesen tomadas y la experiencia ocurrida recientemente en Texas nos demuestra que el país de la libertad no parece querer seguir este camino.  Referencias:
https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/coronavirus-us-cases.html

67.5k per day at the moment = 472.5k for a week
Threshold for 450k = 64.3k per day
Threshold for 550k = 78.5k per day Cases in a lot of states are increases and cases are now at 70k per day.  Vaccines administered should limit any exponential growth now but still can see an increase in cases.  Just not sure it can get over the 78k per day.

For the just concluded week, US is averaging about 490K. It seems there is a skew rightward for two reasons- major one is falling numbers of tests to find a positive case (even though number of tests have been increasing) & the minor reason is there seems to be a upward trend from the week before. With the number of vaccinations going up, there seems to be an air of 'letting your hair down'- which may not bode well.

We are tracking over 450K now, and cases are rising, so the likely range is 450K to 550K.  With the variants and more opening by younger people, this could easily keep rising.  Vaccines may start to impact this later in the month, or perhaps people will become more cautious.
Forecasts seem to sit between 440000 and 480000, and I think the curve seems to indicate a slight increase. However, vaccination rates continue to go up.
This week there was a surge. This is usually followed by a reduction caused by a combination of new state restrictions and by people behaving more cautiously when there is awareness of a surge.

I doubt cases/day will decline over this period because B.1.1.7 is now dominant, and many susceptibles will remain, even after all who want a vaccine has received at least one dose: at least susceptible 60M children and perhaps as many as 65M * 0.6 people age 16+ (who have refused a vaccine but have not had the virus), for a total of approx. 100M = almost 1/3 of the US population.
Cases currently at about 68k/day. 68k cases/day * 7 days = 476k cases. This is a lower bound for the week, imo.
I suspect cases will go up because of B.1.1.7. How far is the question.
On one side: vaccines, natural immunity, spring weather.
On the other side: B.1.1.7, relaxing government policies, relaxing personal attitudes.
But given the large percentage of the population that is still susceptible and the experiences of other countries in which B.1.1.7 has become dominant so far, I suspect we will see a bit of a surge of cases in the US.
550k cases: 78.6k cases/day
650k cases: 92.9k cases/day
750k cases: 107.1k cases/day
850k cases: 121.4k cases/day
I don't completely rule any of these possibilities out, although I think the upper brackets are less likely; we should have seen more growth by now if they were likely.
The past 2 days have been >80k cases/day. I think this trend is likely to continue.

67.5k per day at the moment = 472.5k for a week
Threshold for 450k = 64.3k per day
Threshold for 550k = 78.5k per day Cases in a lot of states are steady or increasing.  Vaccines administered should limit any exponential growth now but still can see an increase in cases.  Just not sure it can get over the 78k per day.

Using https://viz.covid19forecasthub.org/:
Following USC-SI_kJalpha more closely than the ensemble, but keeping the options wide

Expecting similar numbers, with a gradual increase more likely. Allowing wide margin but tending towards 510K.
Forecast range 400,000-530,000

The ensemble model projects it holding steady, with a 95% confidence interval of 220k to 760k the week of May 1st. I think steady seems pretty reasonable, and I think vaccinations could potentially reduce cases a bit, but I don't think they're widespread enough to have a big effect over the next month. Model: https://viz.covid19forecasthub.org/ Weekly cases: https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=40..latest&pickerSort=asc&pickerMetric=location&Metric=Confirmed+cases&Interval=Weekly&Relative+to+Population=false&Align+outbreaks=false&country=~USA
